title: How to Make Hina Matsuri Dolls

methods.name:
Method One: Paper Doll[1]
	X
		Research source
		
				

[2]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Cut the body and head from white cardstock.
steps.description: Use a sharp pair of scissors to cut a small head and body for doll from a sheet of white or ivory cardstock. The head should be 0.8 inch (2 cm) in diameter. Trace the perimeter of a U.S. nickel if you need help sizing the head. The body should be 1/8 inch (3 mm) wide and about 2 inches (5 cm) long.

steps.headline: Cut paper for a collar.
steps.description: Use your scissors to cut a 1-inch (2.5-cm) long piece of 0.6-inch (1.5-cm) wide chiyogami paper. This strip of paper will become the collar of the doll. Note that you will need to use the same type of paper to create the "obi" of the doll later on. This paper should also coordinate with the other two pieces of chiyogami paper you'll be using, but it should not be the exact same pattern.

steps.headline: Fold the collar paper around the body.
steps.description: Place the collar strip behind the body strip. Fold the ends of the collar diagonally down and over the front of the body. Fold the collar strip in half before placing it around the body. The body and collar should be perpendicular when you place the collar behind the body strip. For the sake of accuracy, fold the collar so that the left end goes under the right. The opposite folding is only used for the deceased. Use glue or tape to hold the collar in place.

steps.headline: Create an edge on the primary chiyogami paper.
Attach the body to the kimono.
steps.description: Center the body paper over the top of the kimono paper. Tape or glue the pieces together. Turn the kimono paper over so that the wrong side faces up. The body paper should be centered along the raised edge of the kimono. Position the body so that its attached collar just barely peeks out above the edge of the kimono.

steps.headline: Fold the left corner over.
steps.description: Bring the left corner of the kimono paper diagonally down, folding it over the inner collar and the body. Only crease the kimono paper along the folded edge and just beneath the folded edge. Do not crease it along the entire fold.

steps.headline: Fold in the rest of the left side.
steps.description: Fold the rest of the kimono's left edge toward the center and over the body paper. Crease down the entire left side fold. The left side of the kimono paper should be folded into a vertical edge, creating a straight body. If a corner of the kimono collar extends beyond the rest of the edge, use scissors to trim it off.

steps.headline: Repeat with the right side.
steps.description: Fold the right corner diagonally down over the front of the doll. Fold the entire right edge toward the center, over the front of the doll. When folding the right corner, only crease the top of the folded edge. The right side creased fold should be vertical, making the entire body straight. Trim any excess kimono collar sticking out from beneath this fold. Make sure that the fold angles of the left and right sides are mirrored and equal. The right edge should not cover the left edge completely. Leave 1/8-inch (3-mm) or so of the left side visible. Glue or tape the folded right edge to the body to hold the kimono in place.

steps.headline: Cut a piece of paper for the obi.
steps.description: Cut a strip of your 0.6-inch (1.5-cm) wide paper measuring roughly 1.6-inch (4-cm) long. This strip of paper will become the obi. Note that this strip should be cut from the same paper as the inner collar.

steps.headline: Fold the obi around the kimono.
steps.description: Place the obi strip over the front of the kimono. Fold it so that the ends overlap behind the kimono and tape or glue it in place. The length of the obi should be perpendicular to the body as you place it on top. The top edge of the obi paper should land right around the angled corner of the kimono edge. Trim any excess obi paper at the back of the doll before adhering it in place.

steps.headline: Cut a piece of paper for the obijime.
steps.description: Cut a 1.6-inch (4-cm) long strip of 0.4-inch (1-cm) wide chiyogami paper. This paper will become the obijime that goes over the obi. Choose a coordinating yet different pattern of paper for this strip.

steps.headline: Fold the obijime over the obi.
steps.description: Center the obijime over the obi. Fold the ends so that they meet at the back of the doll, then glue or tape the ends in place. Place the obijime around the body in the same way you placed the obi. Note that the obijime should be centered over the obi.

steps.headline: Attach the head to the body.
steps.description: Glue or tape one side of the cardstock head to the visible top of the body strip. Note that only a very small portion of the body strip should be visible after you do this. This small portion is the neck of the doll.

steps.headline: Create hair from black cardstock.
steps.description: Cut out bangs from the cardstock. Cut out a separate piece of black cardstock to form the back of the hair. You can design a hairstyle to your liking. Just keep in mind that the bangs and back should both be a little wider than the width of the head.

steps.headline: Adhere the hair to the head.
steps.description: Position the bangs on top of the head and glue or tape them in place. Position the back hair piece at the back of the head and glue or tape in place. Note that the back hair piece should also fall behind the kimono of the doll.

steps.headline: Step back and admire your work.
steps.description: The paper Hina Matsuri doll is now complete.

methods.name:
Method Two: Wooden Peg Doll[3]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Paint the surface of a styrofoam ball.
steps.description: Paint an even, solid layer of white paint over a small styrofoam ball. The diameter of the ball should be about 1.5 inch (3.8-cm), or a little less than half the length of the clothespin you'll be using for the doll's body. Let the paint dry before you proceed past this step. If you don't want to paint the ball, you could wrap it in white organza or white nylons instead.

steps.headline: Skewer the ball.
steps.description: Insert the pointed end of a wooden skewer into one side of the ball. Choose a skewer that can slip securely into the gap of the clothespin you'll be using. Only insert the skewer halfway into the ball. Do not poke through to the other side. Make sure that the skewer goes into the ball at a straight angle. The portion of the skewer sticking out of the ball should be about as long as the gap in the clothespin. If necessary, trim it down using heavy scissors or a small saw.

steps.headline: Insert the skewer into the clothespin gap.
steps.description: Slip the exposed portion of the skewer down into the gap of the clothespin. Leave 1/4 inch (6 mm) of the skewer exposed in between the top of the clothespin and the head to serve as a neck. Ideally, pressure should be enough to hold the skewer in place. If it wants to move around inside of the gap, though, you can secure it in place with a little glue. Let the glue dry before continuing.

steps.headline: Cut black crepe paper hair.
steps.description: You'll need to cut out one strip of paper for the bangs and a second strip for the back of the hair. The bangs should be wide enough to wrap around half of the ball. They should be tall enough extend from the middle of the top of the head down to the middle front of the face. The back of the hair should be wide enough to wrap around half of the ball. The length of this piece can be as long as you would like it to be.

steps.headline: Attach the hair to the head.
steps.description: Cover the entire top half of the head with a thin coat of glue. Lay the back of the hair on first, followed by the bangs. The back piece must begin at the top of the head. Press this piece of black crepe paper onto the glue at the back of the head. It should naturally crease and flow back, away from the body, as a result. The bangs must also begin at the top of the head. Press them down over the glue at the front of the head and allow them to slightly overlap the edges of the back piece. Let the glue dry before continuing.

steps.headline: Rest the clothespin in its base.
steps.description: Stick the bottom of the clothespin body firmly into a matching clothespin base. This base will allow the doll to stand upright.

steps.headline: Roll a strip of cardboard into a tube.
steps.description: Cut a piece of thin cardboard into a strip and wrap this strip around the clothespin body of the doll. Glue the edges together and let them dry before continuing. The strip of cardboard should be as tall as the total height of the clothespin and clothespin base. The tube should have a diameter that matches the diameter of the base. You should be able to slip the tube over the body of the doll from below.

steps.headline: Crease the top of the cardboard tube.
steps.description: Use your thumb and index finger to crease the top of the tube on either side of the clothespin. These creased, flattened portions of the tube will form shoulders. They should be positioned below the sides of the head, not below the front and back of the head. Only crease the top 1 inch (2.5 cm) or so of the top. Do not crease down the entire side of the tube.

steps.headline: Remove a piece of cardboard at the front.
steps.description: Carefully cut out a small rectangular section of cardboard at the front of the tube. The rectangle should extend down about as far as the creases in your cardboard. The width of this rectangular portion should only be about as wide as the top of the clothespin. Removing this portion of cardboard will make it easier to add a collar to the doll.

steps.headline: Create a collar for the doll.
steps.description: Cut a long strip of washi paper. Add a solid line of colored origami paper to the top of this strip. The strip of washi paper should be about 1.5 inches (3.8 cm) wide and 5 inches (12.7 cm) long. The strip of solid color origami paper should be about 1/4 inch (6 mm) wide and 5 inches (12.7 cm) long. Glue the solid origami paper over the top edge of the washi paper. Let this dry before continuing.

steps.headline: Attach the collar to the doll.
steps.description: Wrap the collar around the skewer so that the two ends of the collar overlap at the front of the doll. The left end should be folded beneath the right end of the collar for the sake of accuracy. Slip the left end under the rectangular notch you cut from the front of the cardboard tube. This will help hold the collar in place. Leave the right end out and hold it in place with a little glue.

steps.headline: Cut two pieces of paper for the sleeves.
steps.description: Cut two rectangles from the same washi paper. Both should be twice as long as the length of the clothespin body. The width of both rectangles should approximately match the length of the clothespin. Fold the long edge of both pieces in half. Crease well. The sleeves will be made from these double-thick pieces of paper.

steps.headline: Snip around the edges to create the sleeve shape.
steps.description: Round the bottom inside corner and cut a notch into the bottom outer corner. Turn the paper so that the folded edge is either on the right or left side. Locate the bottom corner of the folded edge. Round this off carefully with your scissors. Cut a horizontal line into the open edge of the paper roughly one-third of the way down from the top. This line should only be about 1 inch (2.5 cm) long. Cut a diagonal line from the inner edge of the previous cut down to the bottom corner of the open edge. Remove and discard the paper that falls out when you connect the two cuts. Complete this step for both of the sleeves.

steps.headline: Attach the sleeves to the body of the doll.
steps.description: Glue the open edge of the sleeve to the center back of the doll. The top edge of the cardboard body should align to the top edge of the washi paper sleeve. Position the sleeve paper so that it lies under the hair of the doll. Glue enough of the sleeve over the side and front of the doll to meet the previously attached collar. Let the rest of the sleeve hang loose at the side. Repeat this step for both sleeves.

steps.headline: Cut a piece of paper for the skirt.
steps.description: Cut another rectangle using the same washi paper. Make sure that it is long enough to wrap around the bottom of the cardboard tube. The skirt only needs to be tall/wide enough to stretch from the bottom of the folded collar edge to the bottom of the doll.

steps.headline: Attach the skirt to the body.
steps.description: Wrap the skirt piece around the body. Glue the edges in place along the left side of the doll. The exposed edge will mimic the edge of the kimono. Do not worry if there is still a visible gap of cardboard showing from beneath the washi paper. The obi will cover it.

steps.headline: Cut a strip of paper for the obi.
steps.description: Cut a strip of paper that is about 2 inches (5 cm) wide and long enough to wrap around the body of the doll. The obi needs to be wide enough to cover the exposed part of the cardboard. If 2 inches (5 cm) is not quite wide enough, make it a little wider. Do not use the same washi paper for the obi. You can use either solid color origami paper or a separate piece of washi paper with a different pattern.

steps.headline: Glue the obi around the body of the doll.
steps.description: Wrap the obi strip around the midsection of the body, covering the previously exposed cardboard. Glue it in place and let the glue dry. Note that the ends of the obi strip should be hidden at the back of the doll.

steps.headline: Put the finished doll on display.
steps.description: Your wooden peg Hina Matsuri doll is now complete and ready to show off.

Method One: Paper Doll[1] X Research source [2] X Research source Cut the body and head from white cardstock. Use a sharp pair of scissors to cut a small head and body for doll from a sheet of white or ivory cardstock. The head should be 0.8 inch (2 cm) in diameter. Trace the perimeter of a U.S. nickel if you need help sizing the head. The body should be 1/8 inch (3 mm) wide and about 2 inches (5 cm) long. Cut paper for a collar. Use your scissors to cut a 1-inch (2.5-cm) long piece of 0.6-inch (1.5-cm) wide chiyogami paper. This strip of paper will become the collar of the doll. Note that you will need to use the same type of paper to create the "obi" of the doll later on. This paper should also coordinate with the other two pieces of chiyogami paper you'll be using, but it should not be the exact same pattern. Fold the collar paper around the body. Place the collar strip behind the body strip. Fold the ends of the collar diagonally down and over the front of the body. Fold the collar strip in half before placing it around the body. The body and collar should be perpendicular when you place the collar behind the body strip. For the sake of accuracy, fold the collar so that the left end goes under the right. The opposite folding is only used for the deceased. Use glue or tape to hold the collar in place. Create an edge on the primary chiyogami paper. Take a 2.2-inch by 4.9-inch (5.5-cm by 12.5-cm) sheet of chiyogami paper and double fold the shorter end to create a ridge. This sheet of paper will form the kimono, and this ridge or edge will become the collar of the kimono. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/72\/Make-Hina-Matsuri-Dolls-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-Hina-Matsuri-Dolls-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/7\/72\/Make-Hina-Matsuri-Dolls-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/aid5283343-v4-728px-Make-Hina-Matsuri-Dolls-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

If the paper pattern has a top and bottom, do this at the top of the paper. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/79\/Make-Hina-Matsuri-Dolls-Step-4Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-Hina-Matsuri-Dolls-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/7\/79\/Make-Hina-Matsuri-Dolls-Step-4Bullet2.jpg\/aid5283343-v4-728px-Make-Hina-Matsuri-Dolls-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

\n<\/p><\/div>"} Flip the paper back over to the front. Fold 0.2-inch (0.5-cm) from your previous fold back over to the front, creating a raised edge. Attach the body to the kimono. Center the body paper over the top of the kimono paper. Tape or glue the pieces together. Turn the kimono paper over so that the wrong side faces up. The body paper should be centered along the raised edge of the kimono. Position the body so that its attached collar just barely peeks out above the edge of the kimono. Fold the left corner over. Bring the left corner of the kimono paper diagonally down, folding it over the inner collar and the body. Only crease the kimono paper along the folded edge and just beneath the folded edge. Do not crease it along the entire fold. Fold in the rest of the left side. Fold the rest of the kimono's left edge toward the center and over the body paper. Crease down the entire left side fold. The left side of the kimono paper should be folded into a vertical edge, creating a straight body. If a corner of the kimono collar extends beyond the rest of the edge, use scissors to trim it off. Repeat with the right side. Fold the right corner diagonally down over the front of the doll. Fold the entire right edge toward the center, over the front of the doll. When folding the right corner, only crease the top of the folded edge. The right side creased fold should be vertical, making the entire body straight. Trim any excess kimono collar sticking out from beneath this fold. Make sure that the fold angles of the left and right sides are mirrored and equal. The right edge should not cover the left edge completely. Leave 1/8-inch (3-mm) or so of the left side visible. Glue or tape the folded right edge to the body to hold the kimono in place. Cut a piece of paper for the obi. Cut a strip of your 0.6-inch (1.5-cm) wide paper measuring roughly 1.6-inch (4-cm) long. This strip of paper will become the obi. Note that this strip should be cut from the same paper as the inner collar. Fold the obi around the kimono. Place the obi strip over the front of the kimono. Fold it so that the ends overlap behind the kimono and tape or glue it in place. The length of the obi should be perpendicular to the body as you place it on top. The top edge of the obi paper should land right around the angled corner of the kimono edge. Trim any excess obi paper at the back of the doll before adhering it in place. Cut a piece of paper for the obijime. Cut a 1.6-inch (4-cm) long strip of 0.4-inch (1-cm) wide chiyogami paper. This paper will become the obijime that goes over the obi. Choose a coordinating yet different pattern of paper for this strip. Fold the obijime over the obi. Center the obijime over the obi. Fold the ends so that they meet at the back of the doll, then glue or tape the ends in place. Place the obijime around the body in the same way you placed the obi. Note that the obijime should be centered over the obi. Attach the head to the body. Glue or tape one side of the cardstock head to the visible top of the body strip. Note that only a very small portion of the body strip should be visible after you do this. This small portion is the neck of the doll. Create hair from black cardstock. Cut out bangs from the cardstock. Cut out a separate piece of black cardstock to form the back of the hair. You can design a hairstyle to your liking. Just keep in mind that the bangs and back should both be a little wider than the width of the head. Adhere the hair to the head. Position the bangs on top of the head and glue or tape them in place. Position the back hair piece at the back of the head and glue or tape in place. Note that the back hair piece should also fall behind the kimono of the doll. Step back and admire your work. The paper Hina Matsuri doll is now complete. Method Two: Wooden Peg Doll[3] X Research source Paint the surface of a styrofoam ball. Paint an even, solid layer of white paint over a small styrofoam ball. The diameter of the ball should be about 1.5 inch (3.8-cm), or a little less than half the length of the clothespin you'll be using for the doll's body. Let the paint dry before you proceed past this step. If you don't want to paint the ball, you could wrap it in white organza or white nylons instead. Skewer the ball. Insert the pointed end of a wooden skewer into one side of the ball. Choose a skewer that can slip securely into the gap of the clothespin you'll be using. Only insert the skewer halfway into the ball. Do not poke through to the other side. Make sure that the skewer goes into the ball at a straight angle. The portion of the skewer sticking out of the ball should be about as long as the gap in the clothespin. If necessary, trim it down using heavy scissors or a small saw. Insert the skewer into the clothespin gap. Slip the exposed portion of the skewer down into the gap of the clothespin. Leave 1/4 inch (6 mm) of the skewer exposed in between the top of the clothespin and the head to serve as a neck. Ideally, pressure should be enough to hold the skewer in place. If it wants to move around inside of the gap, though, you can secure it in place with a little glue. Let the glue dry before continuing. Cut black crepe paper hair. You'll need to cut out one strip of paper for the bangs and a second strip for the back of the hair. The bangs should be wide enough to wrap around half of the ball. They should be tall enough extend from the middle of the top of the head down to the middle front of the face. The back of the hair should be wide enough to wrap around half of the ball. The length of this piece can be as long as you would like it to be. Attach the hair to the head. Cover the entire top half of the head with a thin coat of glue. Lay the back of the hair on first, followed by the bangs. The back piece must begin at the top of the head. Press this piece of black crepe paper onto the glue at the back of the head. It should naturally crease and flow back, away from the body, as a result. The bangs must also begin at the top of the head. Press them down over the glue at the front of the head and allow them to slightly overlap the edges of the back piece. Let the glue dry before continuing. Rest the clothespin in its base. Stick the bottom of the clothespin body firmly into a matching clothespin base. This base will allow the doll to stand upright. Roll a strip of cardboard into a tube. Cut a piece of thin cardboard into a strip and wrap this strip around the clothespin body of the doll. Glue the edges together and let them dry before continuing. The strip of cardboard should be as tall as the total height of the clothespin and clothespin base. The tube should have a diameter that matches the diameter of the base. You should be able to slip the tube over the body of the doll from below. Crease the top of the cardboard tube. Use your thumb and index finger to crease the top of the tube on either side of the clothespin. These creased, flattened portions of the tube will form shoulders. They should be positioned below the sides of the head, not below the front and back of the head. Only crease the top 1 inch (2.5 cm) or so of the top. Do not crease down the entire side of the tube. Remove a piece of cardboard at the front. Carefully cut out a small rectangular section of cardboard at the front of the tube. The rectangle should extend down about as far as the creases in your cardboard. The width of this rectangular portion should only be about as wide as the top of the clothespin. Removing this portion of cardboard will make it easier to add a collar to the doll. Create a collar for the doll. Cut a long strip of washi paper. Add a solid line of colored origami paper to the top of this strip. The strip of washi paper should be about 1.5 inches (3.8 cm) wide and 5 inches (12.7 cm) long. The strip of solid color origami paper should be about 1/4 inch (6 mm) wide and 5 inches (12.7 cm) long. Glue the solid origami paper over the top edge of the washi paper. Let this dry before continuing. Attach the collar to the doll. Wrap the collar around the skewer so that the two ends of the collar overlap at the front of the doll. The left end should be folded beneath the right end of the collar for the sake of accuracy. Slip the left end under the rectangular notch you cut from the front of the cardboard tube. This will help hold the collar in place. Leave the right end out and hold it in place with a little glue. Cut two pieces of paper for the sleeves. Cut two rectangles from the same washi paper. Both should be twice as long as the length of the clothespin body. The width of both rectangles should approximately match the length of the clothespin. Fold the long edge of both pieces in half. Crease well. The sleeves will be made from these double-thick pieces of paper. Snip around the edges to create the sleeve shape. Round the bottom inside corner and cut a notch into the bottom outer corner. Turn the paper so that the folded edge is either on the right or left side. Locate the bottom corner of the folded edge. Round this off carefully with your scissors. Cut a horizontal line into the open edge of the paper roughly one-third of the way down from the top. This line should only be about 1 inch (2.5 cm) long. Cut a diagonal line from the inner edge of the previous cut down to the bottom corner of the open edge. Remove and discard the paper that falls out when you connect the two cuts. Complete this step for both of the sleeves. Attach the sleeves to the body of the doll. Glue the open edge of the sleeve to the center back of the doll. The top edge of the cardboard body should align to the top edge of the washi paper sleeve. Position the sleeve paper so that it lies under the hair of the doll. Glue enough of the sleeve over the side and front of the doll to meet the previously attached collar. Let the rest of the sleeve hang loose at the side. Repeat this step for both sleeves. Cut a piece of paper for the skirt. Cut another rectangle using the same washi paper. Make sure that it is long enough to wrap around the bottom of the cardboard tube. The skirt only needs to be tall/wide enough to stretch from the bottom of the folded collar edge to the bottom of the doll. Attach the skirt to the body. Wrap the skirt piece around the body. Glue the edges in place along the left side of the doll. The exposed edge will mimic the edge of the kimono. Do not worry if there is still a visible gap of cardboard showing from beneath the washi paper. The obi will cover it. Cut a strip of paper for the obi. Cut a strip of paper that is about 2 inches (5 cm) wide and long enough to wrap around the body of the doll. The obi needs to be wide enough to cover the exposed part of the cardboard. If 2 inches (5 cm) is not quite wide enough, make it a little wider. Do not use the same washi paper for the obi. You can use either solid color origami paper or a separate piece of washi paper with a different pattern. Glue the obi around the body of the doll. Wrap the obi strip around the midsection of the body, covering the previously exposed cardboard. Glue it in place and let the glue dry. Note that the ends of the obi strip should be hidden at the back of the doll. Put the finished doll on display. Your wooden peg Hina Matsuri doll is now complete and ready to show off.
sentences:
Method One: Paper Doll[1]
	X
		Research source
		
				

[2]
	X
		Research source Cut the body and head from white cardstock.
Use a sharp pair of scissors to cut a small head and body for doll from a sheet of white or ivory cardstock.
The head should be 0.8 inch (2 cm) in diameter.
Trace the perimeter of a U.S. nickel if you need help sizing the head.
The body should be 1/8 inch (3 mm) wide and about 2 inches (5 cm) long.
Cut paper for a collar.
Use your scissors to cut a 1-inch (2.5-cm) long piece of 0.6-inch (1.5-cm) wide chiyogami paper.
This strip of paper will become the collar of the doll.
Note that you will need to use the same type of paper to create the "obi" of the doll later on.
This paper should also coordinate with the other two pieces of chiyogami paper you'll be using, but it should not be the exact same pattern.
Fold the collar paper around the body.
Place the collar strip behind the body strip.
Fold the ends of the collar diagonally down and over the front of the body.
Fold the collar strip in half before placing it around the body.
The body and collar should be perpendicular when you place the collar behind the body strip.
For the sake of accuracy, fold the collar so that the left end goes under the right.
The opposite folding is only used for the deceased.
Use glue or tape to hold the collar in place.
Create an edge on the primary chiyogami paper.
Take a 2.2-inch by 4.9-inch (5.5-cm by 12.5-cm) sheet of chiyogami paper and double fold the shorter end to create a ridge.
This sheet of paper will form the kimono, and this ridge or edge will become the collar of the kimono.

\n<\/p><\/div>"} Flip the paper so that it is wrong-side up.
Fold 0.4-inch (1-cm) of the short end up.
If the paper pattern has a top and bottom, do this at the top of the paper.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/79\/Make-Hina-Matsuri-Dolls-Step-4Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-Hina-Matsuri-Dolls-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/7\/79\/Make-Hina-Matsuri-Dolls-Step-4Bullet2.jpg\/aid5283343-v4-728px-Make-Hina-Matsuri-Dolls-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Flip the paper back over to the front.
Fold 0.2-inch (0.5-cm) from your previous fold back over to the front, creating a raised edge.
Attach the body to the kimono.
Center the body paper over the top of the kimono paper.
Tape or glue the pieces together.
Turn the kimono paper over so that the wrong side faces up.
The body paper should be centered along the raised edge of the kimono.
Position the body so that its attached collar just barely peeks out above the edge of the kimono.
Fold the left corner over.
Bring the left corner of the kimono paper diagonally down, folding it over the inner collar and the body.
Only crease the kimono paper along the folded edge and just beneath the folded edge.
Do not crease it along the entire fold.
Fold in the rest of the left side.
Fold the rest of the kimono's left edge toward the center and over the body paper.
Crease down the entire left side fold.
The left side of the kimono paper should be folded into a vertical edge, creating a straight body.
If a corner of the kimono collar extends beyond the rest of the edge, use scissors to trim it off.
Repeat with the right side.
Fold the right corner diagonally down over the front of the doll.
Fold the entire right edge toward the center, over the front of the doll.
When folding the right corner, only crease the top of the folded edge.
The right side creased fold should be vertical, making the entire body straight.
Trim any excess kimono collar sticking out from beneath this fold.
Make sure that the fold angles of the left and right sides are mirrored and equal.
The right edge should not cover the left edge completely.
Leave 1/8-inch (3-mm) or so of the left side visible.
Glue or tape the folded right edge to the body to hold the kimono in place.
Cut a piece of paper for the obi.
Cut a strip of your 0.6-inch (1.5-cm) wide paper measuring roughly 1.6-inch (4-cm) long.
This strip of paper will become the obi.
Note that this strip should be cut from the same paper as the inner collar.
Fold the obi around the kimono.
Place the obi strip over the front of the kimono.
Fold it so that the ends overlap behind the kimono and tape or glue it in place.
The length of the obi should be perpendicular to the body as you place it on top.
The top edge of the obi paper should land right around the angled corner of the kimono edge.
Trim any excess obi paper at the back of the doll before adhering it in place.
Cut a piece of paper for the obijime.
Cut a 1.6-inch (4-cm) long strip of 0.4-inch (1-cm) wide chiyogami paper.
This paper will become the obijime that goes over the obi.
Choose a coordinating yet different pattern of paper for this strip.
Fold the obijime over the obi.
Center the obijime over the obi.
Fold the ends so that they meet at the back of the doll, then glue or tape the ends in place.
Place the obijime around the body in the same way you placed the obi.
Note that the obijime should be centered over the obi.
Attach the head to the body.
Glue or tape one side of the cardstock head to the visible top of the body strip.
Note that only a very small portion of the body strip should be visible after you do this.
This small portion is the neck of the doll.
Create hair from black cardstock.
Cut out bangs from the cardstock.
Cut out a separate piece of black cardstock to form the back of the hair.
You can design a hairstyle to your liking.
Just keep in mind that the bangs and back should both be a little wider than the width of the head.
Adhere the hair to the head.
Position the bangs on top of the head and glue or tape them in place.
Position the back hair piece at the back of the head and glue or tape in place.
Note that the back hair piece should also fall behind the kimono of the doll.
Step back and admire your work.
The paper Hina Matsuri doll is now complete.

Method Two: Wooden Peg Doll[3]
	X
		Research source Paint the surface of a styrofoam ball.
Paint an even, solid layer of white paint over a small styrofoam ball.
The diameter of the ball should be about 1.5 inch (3.8-cm), or a little less than half the length of the clothespin you'll be using for the doll's body.
Let the paint dry before you proceed past this step.
If you don't want to paint the ball, you could wrap it in white organza or white nylons instead.
Skewer the ball.
Insert the pointed end of a wooden skewer into one side of the ball.
Choose a skewer that can slip securely into the gap of the clothespin you'll be using.
Only insert the skewer halfway into the ball.
Do not poke through to the other side.
Make sure that the skewer goes into the ball at a straight angle.
The portion of the skewer sticking out of the ball should be about as long as the gap in the clothespin.
If necessary, trim it down using heavy scissors or a small saw.
Insert the skewer into the clothespin gap.
Slip the exposed portion of the skewer down into the gap of the clothespin.
Leave 1/4 inch (6 mm) of the skewer exposed in between the top of the clothespin and the head to serve as a neck.
Ideally, pressure should be enough to hold the skewer in place.
If it wants to move around inside of the gap, though, you can secure it in place with a little glue.
Let the glue dry before continuing.
Cut black crepe paper hair.
You'll need to cut out one strip of paper for the bangs and a second strip for the back of the hair.
The bangs should be wide enough to wrap around half of the ball.
They should be tall enough extend from the middle of the top of the head down to the middle front of the face.
The back of the hair should be wide enough to wrap around half of the ball.
The length of this piece can be as long as you would like it to be.
Attach the hair to the head.
Cover the entire top half of the head with a thin coat of glue.
Lay the back of the hair on first, followed by the bangs.
The back piece must begin at the top of the head.
Press this piece of black crepe paper onto the glue at the back of the head.
It should naturally crease and flow back, away from the body, as a result.
The bangs must also begin at the top of the head.
Press them down over the glue at the front of the head and allow them to slightly overlap the edges of the back piece.
Let the glue dry before continuing.
Rest the clothespin in its base.
Stick the bottom of the clothespin body firmly into a matching clothespin base.
This base will allow the doll to stand upright.
Roll a strip of cardboard into a tube.
Cut a piece of thin cardboard into a strip and wrap this strip around the clothespin body of the doll.
Glue the edges together and let them dry before continuing.
The strip of cardboard should be as tall as the total height of the clothespin and clothespin base.
The tube should have a diameter that matches the diameter of the base.
You should be able to slip the tube over the body of the doll from below.
Crease the top of the cardboard tube.
Use your thumb and index finger to crease the top of the tube on either side of the clothespin.
These creased, flattened portions of the tube will form shoulders.
They should be positioned below the sides of the head, not below the front and back of the head.
Only crease the top 1 inch (2.5 cm) or so of the top.
Do not crease down the entire side of the tube.
Remove a piece of cardboard at the front.
Carefully cut out a small rectangular section of cardboard at the front of the tube.
The rectangle should extend down about as far as the creases in your cardboard.
The width of this rectangular portion should only be about as wide as the top of the clothespin.
Removing this portion of cardboard will make it easier to add a collar to the doll.
Create a collar for the doll.
Cut a long strip of washi paper.
Add a solid line of colored origami paper to the top of this strip.
The strip of washi paper should be about 1.5 inches (3.8 cm) wide and 5 inches (12.7 cm) long.
The strip of solid color origami paper should be about 1/4 inch (6 mm) wide and 5 inches (12.7 cm) long.
Glue the solid origami paper over the top edge of the washi paper.
Let this dry before continuing.
Attach the collar to the doll.
Wrap the collar around the skewer so that the two ends of the collar overlap at the front of the doll.
The left end should be folded beneath the right end of the collar for the sake of accuracy.
Slip the left end under the rectangular notch you cut from the front of the cardboard tube.
This will help hold the collar in place.
Leave the right end out and hold it in place with a little glue.
Cut two pieces of paper for the sleeves.
Cut two rectangles from the same washi paper.
Both should be twice as long as the length of the clothespin body.
The width of both rectangles should approximately match the length of the clothespin.
Fold the long edge of both pieces in half.
Crease well.
The sleeves will be made from these double-thick pieces of paper.
Snip around the edges to create the sleeve shape.
Round the bottom inside corner and cut a notch into the bottom outer corner.
Turn the paper so that the folded edge is either on the right or left side.
Locate the bottom corner of the folded edge.
Round this off carefully with your scissors.
Cut a horizontal line into the open edge of the paper roughly one-third of the way down from the top.
This line should only be about 1 inch (2.5 cm) long.
Cut a diagonal line from the inner edge of the previous cut down to the bottom corner of the open edge.
Remove and discard the paper that falls out when you connect the two cuts.
Complete this step for both of the sleeves.
Attach the sleeves to the body of the doll.
Glue the open edge of the sleeve to the center back of the doll.
The top edge of the cardboard body should align to the top edge of the washi paper sleeve.
Position the sleeve paper so that it lies under the hair of the doll.
Glue enough of the sleeve over the side and front of the doll to meet the previously attached collar.
Let the rest of the sleeve hang loose at the side.
Repeat this step for both sleeves.
Cut a piece of paper for the skirt.
Cut another rectangle using the same washi paper.
Make sure that it is long enough to wrap around the bottom of the cardboard tube.
The skirt only needs to be tall/wide enough to stretch from the bottom of the folded collar edge to the bottom of the doll.
Attach the skirt to the body.
Wrap the skirt piece around the body.
Glue the edges in place along the left side of the doll.
The exposed edge will mimic the edge of the kimono.
Do not worry if there is still a visible gap of cardboard showing from beneath the washi paper.
The obi will cover it.
Cut a strip of paper for the obi.
Cut a strip of paper that is about 2 inches (5 cm) wide and long enough to wrap around the body of the doll.
The obi needs to be wide enough to cover the exposed part of the cardboard.
If 2 inches (5 cm) is not quite wide enough, make it a little wider.
Do not use the same washi paper for the obi.
You can use either solid color origami paper or a separate piece of washi paper with a different pattern.
Glue the obi around the body of the doll.
Wrap the obi strip around the midsection of the body, covering the previously exposed cardboard.
Glue it in place and let the glue dry.
Note that the ends of the obi strip should be hidden at the back of the doll.
Put the finished doll on display.
Your wooden peg Hina Matsuri doll is now complete and ready to show off.
tyn_section: Second coordinating chiyogami paper, 0.4-inch (1 cm) wide
Craft glue or hot glue gun
